question: What is your opinion on internet influencers (e.g., streamers, bloggers, short video creators) increasingly becoming a recognized profession? Please answer briefly in 2–3 sentences.

comments.comment: It's not for me, but I appreciate the medium for those who enjoy it. I know people earn livings this way and I support them fully.
i have a positive opinion on them, it looks like it opens many doors for them and I also enjoy watching their content and their product's recommendations. some of them have really good content.

I don't personally relate or identify with this specific job/career choice but I understand why it is becoming widespread. It seems fitting given the proliferation of social media in the last decade or so.
They are doing something they like to do and have the convenience of doing it online at their own convenience. Many are fortunate to make very good income.

I think it makes sense that being an internet influencer is now seen as a real profession, since so many people rely on them for ideas, advice, and entertainment. They play a big role in shaping trends and connecting with audiences in a way traditional jobs don’t. At the same time, I feel it’s important for the space to stay authentic and responsible.
I find influencers to be annoying. They do not seem to be genuine and I find it silly that people are foolish enough to be affected by them.

Influencers are a great addition to the internet. Not only are they entertaining they have been informative about information that has not broadcast on the news. With this being said I believe this will be the new wave of how we actually get news in the truth.
It’s almost like celebrities in the 90s, there’s really no difference except influencers may be more down to earth and expose more of their personal life at first.

They entertain, pass knowledge and information to the masses, they're the new media houses. While it might seem new to a lot of people,  a number of streamers give insightful and cited information.  As well as entertain.

I think it’s very fun and sort of an easy way to get income all while just living your life. Of course having to keep up with trends after a while people tend to just start following one another. Everyone ends up having/wearing the same thing, no one likes to be creative anymore or unique.

It reminds me of the Tower of Babel in the Bible, the point where people begin to not understand each other anymore. Everyone is building their own brand of themselves, losing constant with each other, while thinking that they are building this one collective mind. I find it disturbing.

I think it's becoming saturated. Everyone now thinks they have something profound to say, everyone wants to chase what others have done. I think it's depressing to watch how everyone thinks they are so unique and important, building their own brand, it reminds me lately of the Tower of Babel in the Bible but I can't explain it in such few characters.

I believe that it is a difficult job to do, but that it is a very crowded profession. I am not sure it is a great benefit to society as a whole, but the Internet addiction of many will keep it funded. Live streaming of one's life has shown to have a negative effect since they often need to be outrageous to gather the views over others.
I think that it has its placed, considering we all value entertainment in the form of TV, or books. It's just another offshoot of the entertainment industry, but more easily accessible by people.
They're OK. But there are too many of them now. They also are mostly fake.
Internet influencers have opened up a world of information. I think they are a good source of information and entertainment. They may have some flaws, but I find them to be beneficial in many ways.

I believe internet influencers exploded during covid when everyone was on lockdown and it became more of a recognized professions these past 2-3 years. Many people think it's easy money or they want to pursue their passion of content creation and once they get enough followers and go viral, they quit their full time jobs and start doing content creation full time.

Influencers becoming a recognized profession is a natural evolution of media and commerce. It reflects a shift in how people consume content and make purchasing decisions, moving from traditional advertising to more personalized and relatable recommendations. While it offers new opportunities for creative individuals, it also raises questions about authenticity, transparency, and the potential for oversaturation in the digital marketplace.
I feel it is a good job but has a lot of responsibility. Influencers should be cognizant of their audience and potential to influence their lives. Behave responsibly.

I do not think it is the best thing at the moment because I feel like people can get the wrong ideas about success from such cases. I also feel like there are probably comparatives that existed in this country that were around long before there was even an internet.
I think it’s great that the everyday person can gain a platform and be relatable to different audiences.
I think it isn't too surprising because a lot of creators are popular. They also seem to make good money from it.
I don’t think they are bad, it’s not easy being famous off those platforms. As a recognized profession, I think they should be made accountable like other profession does.
I think some use their popularity for good and some let the recognition get to their head and they become people no one wants to associate with.

I think it makes sense since a lot of people spend time online and creators can actually make a living from it now. It’s similar to entertainment jobs, just on new platforms. As long as they put in real work, I see it as a valid profession.

I am totally fine with it. I do think they should be willing to make sure that they take accountability for the things that they say though, seeing as how the profession is not as regulated as many other professions are

I think at the very least, streamers and some video creators are currently supplementing and to a limited degree replacing standard news outlets. Many news outlets are preset in what they will say based on a diverse mixup of staff leaning either left or right, making it much harder to find with you. Streamers and Video creators are much more plentiful and precise; By this logic, Its a viable profession path If you can get inital publicity, via signing up with a streaming group. Thats my thoughts
I see it as a great profession. It gives these creators source of money

I think it's pretty cool that people are able to make money from home on the internet by blogging, streaming, etc. However I also think it's important to teach kids that being on the internet isn't just "easy money" and that it's still important to go to college or learn a trade and not rely solely on the internet as a career.

I think it’s awesome. I love following certain influencers who I can personally relate to and I also like that it doesn’t matter what you are promoting or what you’re focusing on there’s a place for everybody as far as being a recognized profession how cool is that that you  get to share your life and beliefs and get paid for it.
I like to watch them demonstrate new products. I also look for recommendations from them.
I think they have become industry changers and movers. They have changed how advertisement and product promotion is done as well as political and social narratives online.

I think it's kind of weird how invested people are in others' lives to the point of paying these streamers to create content, but I suppose it makes sense that it would be starting to become a recognized profession. I don't think it should be, but at the same time, some people dedicate their lives to creating Youtube content for a living, too.

I think it's great that the internet has given people opportunities they never would have had otherwise. People are able to work from anywhere as an influencer. It's enabled more people to access entertainment and information easier than ever before.

Yes social media videos are basically replacing Television, which is really dying. I think it's a fantastic thing, because it democratizes who gets to become a celebrity and make a good living from it. I don't want a cabal of evil, super rich globalist scumbags to decide who we can and can't watch.
Problematic when viewers solely get their news from internet influencers. Then subsequently regurgitate  the streamer's viewpoints in a uncritical fashion.
Like everything it has it’s good and bad, good because  we can learn things or they can use their platforms to spread awareness ,bad because it’s easier to misuse their platforms to misinformation.

I think internet influencers becoming a recognized profession is sort of silly but at the same time it does take effort to keep audiences entertained and having to edit videos is not easy. It's not something a kid should aspire to become but it could work as a side gig/hustle, it should not be a main job for anyone in my opinion.

I think if people can figure out a way to succeed in it, good for them. People exploit themselves for money everyday and this isn’t a new concept, it’s just the first time it’s being capitalized and documented to this extent.
I think it's good that people can become entrepreneurs. They help out ordinary people.

I think it's great that more and more people are becoming influencers because the more people become influencers, the more competition there is for better content, more accurate content, and so forth. For example, the more beauty and skincare influencers there are, the more competitive it becomes to create accurate, entertaining, and professional skincare and beauty content for the viewers.
I think it's a unique profession! Unfortunately, the way the internet is monetized is very detrimental, especially to younger audiences.

It is ridiculous the amount of money these folks make as compared to more traditionally "respectable" jobs, like doctor, engineer, etc. I believe influencers and creators promote excessive overconsumption.
It's fine that it's a profession, but I don't think many of them have the best interest of others at heart. I think many of them are in it just for grifting money off their fans.
I think its great for people to be self employed and have others ways to make money besides corporate America.  It also gives other people a perspective and influence from someone like them.
Rather than encouraging future children to pursue studies, research, or more advanced careers, they will be more drawn to easy and stimulating things like influencers.

I understand that they put in a lot of work to make their content, but It seems like a copout job for kids that are now growing up. Kids want to take the easy route to making a living instead of going to college.

As a person who watched the web crawl, then sprint, I see influencers as a real trade: part entertainer, part marketer, part small business owner (with all the headaches). Done with integrity, it widens who gets paid for creative labor, grows culture, and builds communities; the catch is that algorithms behave like fickle bosses, so creators need fair contracts, unions, and safety nets. Teach media literacy, require transparency about ads and AI, and I’m comfortable calling it a profession.

I agree with internet influencers such as streamers, bloggers, short video creators as becoming more increasingly more recognized as an actual profession because they generate income from providing this form of publicized entertainment. An internet influencer such as Mr. Beast starts has created a life based on their internet antics and often by doing this, it can create large streams of incomes from the vast number of followers and watchers of this individual's widely popular streaming content.
My opinion on internet influencers is that I think they like the attention. I think that they are people that are  extroverts.

To be an internet influencer you need to be so insanely lucky, that I don't think it is a viable option for literally 99.99% of the population.  It anything it should be something more akin to a side hustle, and not the main pursuit for literally anyone. It is probably on the level of winning the lottery in luck needed to become an influencer. As for it being a profession, it should be recognized as a profession. It is a job where a person needs to put in a certain amount of work.
I think it's something we've seen before but in a more accessible form. YouTubers used to be a big thing, but now we've moved toward Tiktok and Instagram content.
I think it’s great. It gives them an opportunity to make money and teach and audience.
I dislike them because they’re just attention seeking people who say anything for some social media engagement. They have no actual influence over anyone with half a brain.
I think some internet influencers are genuine and others are so fake. The fake ones make the rest look bad, so it makes it hard to believe who is genuine and who isn’t.

I think it is great that people are able to put themselves out there and share their ideas. I think being an influencer is a great way to make a living without having to get an education, which can be very expensive.
There is a lot of them now and more ways to earn online. Sponsorships have really changed how people view the profession.

At first, I was a bit skeptical at the validity of it being a job. I didn't understand how someone could realistically make enough money to live just by having "followers" and promoting products. Currently, I think that having that opportunity to make a living from the internet is a great opportunity and one that many people would want to accomplish. It doesn't seem easy or a well formed path, but one that is worth going down if you can commit.
It's great that influencers are getting more recognition. There are many hats worn for this particular profession and it shouldn't be downplayed as being a lesser job for the freedom it grants.
I think that it is a valid profession. Many of them provide great news updates and access to information for the public.

I'm conceptually fine with it, as I believe a quality content creator provides a lot of value and entertainment, as well as generate actual discussion around unconventional topics. That being said, it's also mired in slop and click-baiting with undeserving idiots garnering a platform.
I think it's annoying. They make lots of money just being on Youtube. People follow them mindlessly.
i think its a joke. They spread misinformation. And are paid to spread misinformation

The emergence of internet influencers as a recognized profession showcases the digital landscape's evolution. Creators can now monetize their passions, building careers, but this shift also sparks discussions about sustainability, responsibility, and industry standards, highlighting the complexity and multifaceted nature of this growing profession. New opportunities abound.

I think it can be good because it creates new jobs, especially since a lot of people are complaining that AI is taking over everyone's jobs. But there are risks to it because some of these influencers may use their platform for malicious purposes, and if they have a large enough platform, it can be harmful to society.
There are several internet influencers that I follow and genuinely enjoy. I am ok with it being known as a profession but is not something that should be considered sustainable in terms of a career.
I think that some are very good that usually share something about their lives that many want to view. Others seem like attention-seeking narcassists.

I find it fascinating! I’ve noticed that it is a very high-risk, opportunistic job that varies widely in both effort and success. However, I find it very comparable to other jobs in the entertainment industry, such as performative arts. The increasing demand for video content provides people with interesting ways to make a living from pursuing their own hobbies, some of which may be otherwise difficult to market

I am happy that everyone can have their five minutes of fame with social media and internet influencing. It gives a platform for common people to exhibit their artistic talents. However I feel the influencers have to diversify in order to remain relevant in this ever changing landscape. Mental health of the creators and the mindless scrolling of the audience are aspects to be concerned about.
I think they are very much needed in today's media landscape. They can bridge the gap between institutions and the news.

In my opinion, the rise of influencers as a recognized profession reflects a fundamental shift in how people consume media and build careers. It's an entrepreneurial path that validates personal brands and content creation, though it comes with unique challenges like job security and constant public scrutiny.

I am not thrilled about it, because I think the low barrier to entry and the fickle nature of the algorithm has allowed people who are not producing anything substantive to monetize their efforts. There are talented creators, but I don't think all of these people are contributing meaningfully to society.

I feel there are a few influencers I like that I feel are genuine and have actual talent as creators, or at the bare minimum an actual voice of their own. But I feel a lot of that culture/sub-culture is not genuine at all. From fashion to self help, and etc. Or just commentary in general. It feels so clean and safe.
It's a legitimate profession in that people can and do make money from it, but I don't think it's a viable career choice for the majority of the population.

I think that as long as it is done responsibly that there is no problem with it. People have a right to make money however they want as long as it is legal. This is just the new wave of opportunity that people are taking.
I don't trust them. You can't be sure the person is actually using the product and has gotten real results.

I like that they are able to show their creative side. I also think that they can help people that are going through similar problems by sharing what they share on the internet. I think it is good to have entertainment and people that you feel you can relate too.

There are many that are just so good, and if it weren't for the internet, and the ability for anyone to be creative and be seen online, we wouldn't know they existed. I think it's great that people can be recognized for their talents and make a living doing it.

I think there is a good and bad regarding influencers. I think they can both be useful and pointless, depending on who it is and who sponsors them. They can be a good influence or bad towards their platforms; whoever looks up to them or follows them.
I am older but I love this as a profession. It takes creativity, content and communication skills to be a great influencer.
I don't follow or care about internet influencers. It's not something I even think about, frankly.
i think it is a joke.  These people are paid to put out an opinion

I like many of the influencers on social media and online in general. They share many of their skills and knowledge on so many topics, and I learned a lot from them. Also, with the status of the economy today, using this means as a source of income/profession is a great idea, because of rise in unemployment. This is a means to take care of ourselves and our families.

I don't have a strong opinion on it. It is a little worrisome that anyone with a camera can say what they want and if they have a strong enough following people will listen. However it is a good way to connect with an audience and some influencers seem more authentic than others.
They live fake lives. They portray themselves to the world like they have such a great life, but they hide what's really going on in their lives behind the scenes.

I enjoy content creators, however even though technically they do influence... I dont like the name "influencer" because some of us can consume content and just enjoy it or be entertained or get SOMETHING from it withOUT being "influenced". Hate that term. Content Creators NOT Influencers.

I don't have any strong opinions on influencers becoming increasingly recognized as a real profession but I do think that it's important that it is recognized that they are essentially paid sponsors.  I think that it's really important that because of this, people don't just take their recommendations as real truth without looking into what they are saying further.  It is important that people look to actual experts on things like health and facts rather than just believing influencers.

I think as someone who grew up a lot with video games, and popular youtubers like pewdiepie. I enjoy it that doing something you love a lot, can be recognized a an actual profession, where you can make a lot of money as well. As a content creator you constantly have to make new content to keep your audience interested as well.

I think it's kind of silly, but I can also respect it. People enjoy media, and it's just an extension of tv or movie stars at this point. However, because it feels more interactive than standard celebrities, I can see why it's popular.

I think that I do see it as a serious profession being a streamer. The amount of time it takes to put together and research that goes into making a video could be hours to maybe even days. The education to learn how to both a film and edit is a skill you could use in a regular nine to five job.

Internet influencers, in my opinion, are artificially portraying an existence that is so much better than their reality.  In the South, there is this saying..,"fake it til you make it."   That ought to be their motto.

My opinion is mostly negative. More and more content creators pivot into treating it like a full-time job rather than a hobby and fail to realize how much they'll need to rely on outside sponsors for money. They all shill the same bad products and services and it gets tiring having to be bombarded by ads constantly when you're trying to relax.

I think it is impressive and show's we are in a new age. Technology has advanced so much we know have a new different profession created from it. I think it is a good thing but with everything you must think about why you want to go into this profession.

It is great to see internet influencers increasingly becoming a recognized profession, especially dating back a few years ago when it was rather shunned. Now, it is possible to make it into a job that inspires tons of kids, which could be a good thing or not, but I believe the good outweighs the bad. However, there are bad apples within the internet influencers here and there, but it is a good thing to make new jobs.
If it works for them that's great. But I have a problem with them getting wealthy doing this while teachers, daycare workers, service wirkers, etc get paid crap.

I do not like it one bit. Most of the influencers I come across advertise products they have never used before and act like experts. I also dislike the fact that they are influencers, because most of them do nothing productive for the world.
